newsitem.title: INDIA: India says will shield domestic firms against MNCs.
newsitem.headline: India says will shield domestic firms against MNCs.

text.p: India's Industry Minister Murasoli Maran said on Thursday the government welcomed foreign investment but would protect domestic firms if they were in danger of being "gobbled up" by multinational corporations (MNCs).
"If we have any substantive information that any particular industry will be gobbled up, we will take precautionary measures," Maran told Reuters in an interview.
"We will give protection just as America gives protection to automobiles and semiconductors. There is nothing wrong in it."
Maran, a free-trade advocate in Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's fractious 13-party centre-left coalition, urged domestic firms not to be afraid of multinational companies.
Indian companies are worried about being swept off their feet by MNCs by the wave of liberalisation India launched in 1991 to dismantle decades of socialist controls.
"There are about 170 Indian MNCs who are there with several billions of rupees equity functioning in many countries of the world. So let us not be afraid of MNCs," Maran said.
Maran pledged to introduce further measures to woo foreign direct investment.
He said the industry ministry had set up a panel to monitor the implementation of large projects set up with foreign investment.

"We have created a cell in my ministry to monitor the mega-projects because there is a gap between approvals and inflows. The percentage has improved from 20-21 percent to 24 percent during the current year. But this is not enough."
The ministry will soon enlarge the panel to focus on Germany, France, Italy and Japan and with an eye on small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in those countries, Maran said.
"All the world is not dominated by the MNCs alone. These SMEs, they play a major role in Europe and in America also. But like MNCs they have no mobility. So we have to go and approach them," he said.
Deve Gowda's centre-left government, after assuming power in June last year, said in a policy blueprint that India can absorb $10 billion of foreign direct investment (FDI) every year.
"Our target is $10 billion," Maran said.
"Since July to now (until December 31) we have already approved FDI to the extent of $10 billion. This is approval. This is a great achievement, it is a feather in the cap of the government."
He did not give comparative FDI approvals for last year.
The coalition government, whose members range from free-traders to communists, has been accused by criticis of speaking in different voices and sending confusing signals to foreign investors.
Asked to comment on the recent government decision to defer a controversial tie-up between India's Tata group and Singapore Airlines Ltd, Maran said:
"Differences of opinion are bound to be there in a democratic society, more so in a United Front government with a 13-party alliance."
SIA and the Tatas have proposed a $600 million tie-up that is opposed by Civil Aviation Minister Chand Mahal Ibrahim.
The proposal to create a new domestic airline has drawn strong support from Maran, whose ministry approved the proposal and forwarded it to the federal cabinet.

Late last month, India approved a new aviation policy that permits foreign investors to hold up to 40 percent stakes in domestic airlines. But the policy does not allow foreign airlines directly to hold stakes.
